Ravenfield even though i wouldn't rate it best game of all time, its the best game i have ever gotten in fact i love the game so much iv'e played it for over 100 hours! that crazy! And im not 100 percent certain why iv'e played it so damn much, i think one of the biggest reasons would be the AMAZING workshop, this game is fueled by the outstanding community and mods. you can make the game into a WW2 game, a modern warfare game, a futuristic game, a silly game, a star wars game, literally anything you like and its easy and accessible! And another thing that really differs it from other war sandboxes is its such variety, there's cars, skins, planes, tanks, jeeps, ATV's, bombers, boats, machine guns, anti tank launchers, chat, names, tons of guns, maps, modes, teams, and everything is customize-able to make the war simulation of your dreams! now i only see two downsides too this game... 1, once you've gone crazy with mods like i have it'll take a while to load into the game but its not a big deal at all. 2, The game can be a lil glitchy when you have planes, tanks, and boats, and 100s of NPCs running everywhere wiiiichhh is understandable but it also depends on your Specs on your pc. but other than that its a great game! theres so much to explore and do youll be spending hours playing like me, so i HIGHLY recommend you purchase and download and start killing some aliens with WW2 era tanks and modern m4a1 rifles!

Great game, but I recommend avoiding some of the community if you can.

As a game, it's wonderful, and I highly recommend it. It's got a few things that are jank like the optimization (when it comes to mods anyway), the over reliance on mods to make this game good (I don't want to hear how it compares to gmod, since gmod was made as a mod platform first), amongst other things, but the gameplay is solid enough to where it doesn't bother me, but as stated, the optimization can be a massive turn off if those don't have mid to high end PCs on some of the mods that require heavy resources on your PC. There are games I believe that take the sandbox aspect and execute it better, but RF is a game that I enjoyed for the game alone, even if I found the base game lacking (even for 18 dollars). Feels more like a game for modders to clean up than the developer making a quality product.

Anyways, onto the community. Now what do I mean by the community being not the sharpest tools in the shed? Some of the community can be rather a bit toxic in the way that they are just egotistical, and having a holier than thou approach to things alongside just being pure gatekeeping morons about it (especially on Discord), and certain big time modders (won't name who) will feel obligated to go behind people's backs (like myself) and dump on some for the sake of it, and it's just disgusting. Had to leave most RF related servers (including RF main) because of this and I wouldn't be surprised if people were to do so without me noticing. I will say not all of the community is bad, but some of them throw me off to a point where I stopped making stuff for about a few weeks.

TLDR: Good game, but not the best community out there.

Pretty decent game, even playing vanilla. I've been playing for around a year now. Graphics aren't the best, but who really cares about them. The gunplay is pretty cool, and the slow motion is a cool touch. With mods, you can transform this game into anything from a tactical shooter straight out of Arma or Escape From Tarkov, or you can turn it into a match where you have 100+ meme mods running while playing on the skeld from fucking amongus with a handheld nuclear launcher in close quarters. But, there are some cons, such as the AI performing aswell as a fetus trying to fly a plane, and a lot of time between updates. You can probably fix both of these with mods, though. Overall, a great, underrated game.

This is an excellent game that brings to mind the singleplayer modes of the older Battlefield games, pre-Battlefield 3. It's focused around a highly-customizable skirmish mode essentially, with the games playing out like a singleplayer version of a Battlefield match, where two teams fight it out over capture points using a selection of weapons and vehicles including aircraft. The gameplay is the tried-and-tested Battlefield formula and it works very well.

The graphics are hardly photorealistic, but they have a charmingly simplistic style that allows the game to run very well even with large numbers of bots, and they nonetheless give a good feel of a raging battle as blood splats and bullet holes mar areas that have been fought over for quite a while afterward. 

Perhaps the area this game shines most is its mod support. With Workshop integration, modding this game is child's play, and it has a large and dedicated community of skilled modders making new maps, weapons, vehicles, and player models. No matter what era of history you want your game to look like, you can probably find it on the Workshop somewhere.

If you loved the feel of the old Battlefield skirmish modes and their moddability, you can't go wrong with Ravenfield. As someone who even now still plays Battlefield 2 sometimes, I highly recommend it.

Tired of buggy CODs, BFs and other broken FPS? Wanna create your own FPS scenario and experience? Then this game is for you!

With tons of mods from Workshop, you can create any type of warfare you want! WW1? WW2? Cold War? Modern Warfare? SPACE WAR? GOT FOR IT!

The game is very worth the money. If you got bored of it, it means you don't use enough mods for your experience!

Wanna play modded multiplayer with your friends? Install the RavenM mod and hop in to play multiplayer for free!

Again, this game is worth the money for anyone who want to enjoy FPS alone or with friends in different types of scenarios and experience!

Ravenfield is an exhilarating and immersive game that delivers non-stop action and endless fun. The gameplay is fast-paced, with intense battles and strategic elements that keep you on the edge of your seat. The graphics are stunning, creating a visually stunning environment that adds to the overall immersive experience. The AI-controlled soldiers provide a challenging and realistic combat scenario, making each engagement feel authentic. The wide array of weapons and vehicles at your disposal allows for endless possibilities and varied gameplay strategies. With its seamless controls and addictive gameplay, Ravenfield is a must-play for any fan of first-person shooters, offering an unforgettable gaming experience that will keep you coming back for more.

If you are looking for a review on Raven field you have come to the wrong place but, I can tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

The negative reviews are worse than this game. None of them explain in full the downsides and upsides of this game, so I will try:

[h1]Gameplay: [/h1]

The game is a battlefield simulator. It does the battlefield simulating part well, but the game part is lacking in all aspects:

Gunplay is confusing. Weapons are highly inaccurate and feel unresponsive to use. It is not at all clear where your shots land due to lack of bullet effects. Bullets stop at everything, which is a weird design choice. By default the game has hitmarkers and kill feed like in a multiplayer arena shooter, which is as stupid as a design choice as it sounds like. Luckily you can disable these.

Even if there is a huge fight going on, you can only play as a single soldier: You cannot order AI soldiers beyond "go here" commands. Even in the planning menu you cannot plan maneuvers, instead only tell soldiers what control points to focus on.

You cannot take control of other soldiers, you must respawn. You can't even lead a squad, unless you recruit random people around your spawnpoint every time you respawn. 

The latter issue is fixed in the Spec Ops gamemode, which feels like a cheap attempt at Ghost Recon mission. Which seems like a great idea except you lose the instant you die, as you cannot take control of other soldiers. And you can't order this squad around, they can either hold in position and die, or follow you and die.

Other than Spec Ops, the game is mainly only control points maps. Some maps are fine enough to play on, but most are very boring and incomplete. It would've been fine to have smaller king-of-the-hill or capture-the-flag maps instead of forcing these small maps into control point gamemode.

[h1] Technical side: [/h1] 

The technical side of this game is a mess. It's not very  laggy or unplayable, but it is not well made. Bullets will hit invisible walls around objects constantly. There is no difference between a steep ground you can walk on and a ramp you will slide off of. You can change your speed whilst jumping as effectively as you can while on the ground.

AI is stupid: It never does tactical maneuvers and never goes for cover, instead running away at a straight angle or sitting still in some pre-designated spot. 

[h1] Potential: [/h1] 

Lets get the obvious out of the way. It's early access, so you shouldn't expect perfection. However, there's no potential here either. The game mechanics are weird combination of battlefield and call of duty series, without the appeal of either.

It's not unplayable. But it has no real benefits compared to those games. Battlefield 2 has one of, if not the best singleplayer instant action experiences. The reason for this is the detail put into every level. There is none of that here. Maps with fun ideas like a lab hanging above a ravine in Glacier are only 2% of the map, rest of it but empty wasteland. Come on, place an underground complex drilled onto a cliff, add some scientist outposts, hell, even basic trenches or forests, anything but empty nothingness.

This game's minimalistic style is it's biggest downfall, don't get me wrong, it isn't bad, but it's utilized incorrectly. The soul of a battle is created through constant sound effects and musical score. This is understood by big battlefield games like Battlefront and even small-scale tactical shooters like Ghost Recon. I am not expecting orchestra from a solo dev, but I am expecting some effort. Hell, this game's trailer has more effort put into it's sound design that the entire game itself.

The battles are confusing and big, so maybe some deep and loud echoes of the distant explosions and constant chatter could be juxtaposed with effective use of natural sounds of wind, birds and grasshoppers in order to create some sort atmosphere? Use less realistic sound effects to get across the feeling of wackiness in these color-coded wars, or utilize loud deathscreams as some distant dude's bodyparts were torn off by an explosion to get across the gritty feel of war. Use music stings when things happen in gameplay, not only when the game has ended.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 

[b]As the Ravenfield stands right now, there is no soul, there is no engaging gameplay, there is no effort. There is no game worth your money.[/b]

I've been wanting to do a review on Ravenfield for a while now, and here I am!
This game has proven itself to be a great joy over the last one or two years, and for the price tag of $17.99, Ravenfield can bring you hours of fun. However I can't fully say to you buy it full price for you not to use the steam modding community, as it pains me to state this; the base game is pretty lackluster.

For the game though, it's truly a work-of-art in the Indie genre, coupled with the amazing modding community you can turn this game from two LEGO teams fighting, into something that somehow rivals mid-budget AAA FPS. (As far as I can tell, outmatches Vanguard.)  
Also for an Indie game, the content and graphics are pretty decent. Even still, Ravenfield can sometimes feel to bright or dark depending on the map or graphic settings. Sadly for me the mouse sensitivity can really make the game unplayable or unenjoyable if not fixed immediately, also the key-bindings could get some improvements.

All-in-all, Ravenfield is a game that seems to be another run-of-the-mill shooters, but in the end it truly is the best indie game I have ever played. I also would like to thank BaronVonGames for revealing this game to me, so if you're reading this Baron, thank you for the almost 100 hours spent on this game..
